operator name to set\n     */\n    public void setOperatorName(String operatorName) {\n        this.operatorName = operatorName;\n    }\n    \n    /**\n     * Gets the total number of customers served.\n     * \n     * @return the total customers served\n     */\n    public int getTotalCustomersServed() {\n        return totalCustomersServed;\n    }\n    \n    /**\n     * Sets the total number of customers served.\n     * \n     * @param totalCustomersServed the total customers served to set\n     */\n    public void setTotalCustomersServed(int totalCustomersServed) {\n        this.totalCustomersServed = totalCustomersServed;\n    }\n    \n    /**\n     * Gets the total revenue generated.\n     * \n     * @return the total revenue in currency units\n     */\n    public int getTotalRevenue() {\n        return totalRevenue;\n    }\n    \n    /**\n     * Sets the total revenue generated.\n     * \n     * @param totalRevenue the total revenue to set (in currency units)\n     */\n    public void setTotalRevenue(int totalRevenue) {\n        this.totalRevenue = totalRevenue;\n    }\n    \n    /**\n     * Gets the average customer rating.\n     * Rating is typically on a scale of 1.0 to 5.0.\n     * \n     * @return the average customer rating\n     */\n    public double getAverageCustomerRating() {\n        return averageCustomerRating;\n    }\n    \n    /**\n     * Sets the average customer rating.\n     * \n     * @param averageCustomerRating the average customer rating to set (1.0 to 5.0)\n     * @throws IllegalArgumentException if rating is outside valid range (1.0-5.0)\n     */\n    public void setAverageCustomerRating(double averageCustomerRating) {\n        if (averageCustomerRating < 1.0 || averageCustomerRating > 5.0) {\n            throw new IllegalArgumentException("Rating must be between 1.0 and 5.0");\n        }\n        this.averageCustomerRating = averageCustomerRating;\n    }\n    \n    /**\n     * Gets the most popular item sold at the refreshment point.\n     * \n     * @return the most popular item\n     */\n    public String getMostPopularItem() {\n        return mostPopularItem;\n    }\n    \n    /**\n     * Sets the most popular item sold at the refreshment point.\n     * \n     * @param mostPopularItem the most popular item to set\n     */\n    public void setMostPopularItem(String mostPopularItem) {\n        this.mostPopularItem = mostPopularItem;\n    }\n    \n    /**\n     * Gets the peak business hours.\n     * Typically represented as time ranges (e.g., "8:00-10:00, 12:00-14:00").\n     * \n     * @return the peak hours\n     */\n    public String getPeakHours() {\n        return peakHours;\n    }\n    \n    /**\n     * Sets the peak business hours.\n     * \n     * @param peakHours the peak hours to set\n     */\n    public void setPeakHours(String peakHours) {\n        this.peakHours = peakHours;\n    }\n    \n    /**\n     * Gets the average revenue per customer.\n     * This is a calculated metric based on total revenue and total customers.\n     * \n     * @return the average revenue per customer\n     */\n    public double getAverageRevenuePerCustomer() {\n        return averageRevenuePerCustomer;\n    }\n    \n    /**\n     * Sets the average revenue per customer.\n     * \n     * @param averageRevenuePerCustomer the average revenue per customer to set\n     */\n    public void setAverageRevenuePerCustomer(double averageRevenuePerCustomer) {\n        this.averageRevenuePerCustomer = averageRevenuePerCustomer;\n    }\n    \n    /**\n     * Gets the customer satisfaction level.\n     * This is a categorical representation based on the average rating.\n     * \n     * @return the satisfaction level (e.g., "Excellent", "Good", "Average", "Needs Improvement")\n     */\n    public String getSatisfactionLevel() {\n        return satisfactionLevel;\n    }\n    \n    /**\n     * Sets the customer satisfaction level.\n     * \n     * @param      this.lastUpdated = lastUpdated;\n    }\n    \n    /**\n     * Returns a formatted string representation of the statistics.\n     * This is useful for displaying the data in a readable format.\n     * \n     * @return formatted string with all statistics\n     */\n    @Override\n    public String toString() {\n        return String.format(\n            "Restaurant Point Statistics:%n" +\n that all required statistics fields are populated.\n     * This method checks for null or invalid values in critical fields.\n     * \n     * @return true if the statistics are valid, false otherwise\n     */\n    public boolean isValid() {\n        return pointId != null && !pointId.isEmpty() &&\n               pointName != null && !pointName.isEmpty() &&\n               operatorName != null && !operatorName.isEmpty() &&\n               totalCustomersServed >= 0 &&\n               totalRevenue >= 0 &&\n               averageCustomerRating >= 1.0 && averageCustomerRating <= 5.0 &&\n Calculates and returns the revenue per customer.\n     * This is a convenience method that performs the calculation on the fly.\n     * \n     * @return revenue per customer, or 0.0 if no customers were served\n     */\n    public double calculateRevenuePerCustomer() {\n        if (totalCustomersServed == 0) {\n            return 0.0;\n        }\n        return (double) totalRevenue / totalCustomersServed;\n    }\n    \n    /**\n     * Updates the last updated timestamp to the current date.\n     * This should be called whenever statistics are modified.\n     */\n    public void statistics\n062|     * @return RestaurantPointStatistics object for the specified date range\n063|     */\n064|    public RestaurantPointStatistics getStatisticsForDateRange(LocalDate startDate, LocalDate endDate) {\n065|        System.out.println("Fetching statistics from " + startDate.format(dateFormatter) + \n066|                          " to " + endDate.format(dateFormatter));\n067|        \n068|        if (!isServerAvailable()) {\n069|            throw new RuntimeException("Connection to statistics server interrupted");\n070|        }\n071|        \n072|        simulateNetworkDelay();\n073|        \n074|        // Generate statistics for the date range\n075|        return generateStatisticsForRange(startDate, endDate);\n076|    }\n077|    \n078|    /**\n079|     * Checks if the statistics server is available.\n080|     * Simulates server availability with a chance of connection interruption.\n081|     * \n082|     * @return true if server is available, false if connection is interrupted\n083|     */\n084|    private boolean isServerAvailable() {\n085|        // Simulate server availability - 80% chance of success\n086|        double availability = random.nextDouble();\n087|        \n088|        if (availability < 0.8) {\n089|            return true;\n090|        } else {\n091|            System.out.println("Warning: Statistics server connection interrupted");\n092|            return false;\n093|        }\n094|    }\n095|    \n096|    /**\n097|     * Simulates network delay for data retrieval.\n098|     * Adds a random delay between 100-500ms.\n099|     */\n100|    private void simulateNetworkDelay() {\n101|        try {\n102|            int delay = 100 + random.nextInt(400); // 100-500ms\n103|            Thread.sleep(delay);\n104|        } catch (InterruptedException e) {\n105|            Thread.currentThread().interrupt();\n106|            System.out.println("Network delay simulation interrupted");\n107|        }\n108|    }\n109|    \n110|    /**\n111|     * Generates sample statistics data for demonstration.\n112|     * \n113|     * @return RestaurantPointStatistics object with sample data\n114|     */\n115|    private RestaurantPointStatistics generateSampleStatistics() {\n116|        LocalDate today = LocalDate.now();\n117|        LocalDate weekStart = today.minusDays(7);\n118|        \n119|        RestaurantPointStatistics stats = new RestaurantPointStatistics();\n120|        stats.setPointId("REST-POINT-" + (1000 + random.nextInt(9000)));\n121|        stats.setPointName("Main Refreshment Point");\n122|        stats.setOperatorName("Operator " + (char)(\'A\' + random.nextInt(26)));\n123|        \n124|        // Generate random statistics data\n125|        stats.setTotalCustomersServed(500 + random.nextInt(500)); // 500-1000\n126|        stats.setTotalRevenue(10000 + random.nextInt(20000)); // 10000-30000\n127|        stats.setAverageCustomerRating(3.5 + random.nextDouble() * 1.5); // 3.5-5.0\n128|        stats.setMostPopularItem("Coffee");\n129|        stats.setPeakHours("8:00-10:00, 12:00-14:00");\n130|        \n131|        // Calculate additional metrics\n132|        calculateAdditionalMetrics(stats);\n133|        \n134|        return stats;\n135|    }\n136|    \n137|    /**\n138|     * Generates statistics for a specific date range.\n139|     * \n140|     * @param startDate the start date\n141|     * @param endDate the end date\n142|     * @return RestaurantPointStatistics object for the date range\n143|     */\n144|    private RestaurantPointStatistics generateStatisticsForRange(LocalDate startDate, LocalDate endDate) {\n145|        RestaurantPointStatistics stats = new RestaurantPointStatistics();\n146|        stats.setPointId("REST-POINT-" + (1000 + random.nextInt(9000)));\n147|        stats.setPointName("Main Refreshment Point");\n148|        stats.setOperatorName("Operator " + (char)(\'A\' + random.nextInt(26)));\n149|        \n150|        // Calculate days in range for realistic data\n151|        long daysInRange = endDate.toEpochDay() - startDate.toEpochDay() + 1;\n152|        \n153|        // Generate proportional statistics based on date range\n154|        int dailyCustomers = 50 + random.nextInt(50); // 50-100 per day\n155|        stats.setTotalCustomersServed((int)(dailyCustomers * daysInRange));\n156|        \n157|        double dailyRevenue = 1000 + random.nextInt(1000); // 1000-2000 per day\n158|        stats.setTotalRevenue((int)(dailyRevenue * daysInRange));\n159|        \n160|        stats.setAverageCustomerRating(3.5 + random.nextDouble() * 1.5); // 3.5-5.0\n161|        stats.setMostPopularItem("Sandwich");\n162|        stats.setPeakHours("11:00-13:00, 17:00-19:00");\n163|        \n164|        calculateAdditionalMetrics(stats);\n165|        \n166|        return stats;\n167|    }\n168|    \n169|    /**\n170|     * Calculates and sets additional metrics based on base statistics.\n171|     * \n172|     * @param stats the RestaurantPointStatistics object to enrich\n173|     */\n174|    private void calculateAdditionalMetrics(RestaurantPointStatistics stats) {\n175|        // Calculate average revenue per customer\n176|        if (stats.getTotalCustomersServed() > 0) {\n177|            double avgRevenuePerCustomer = (double) stats.getTotalRevenue() / stats.getTotalCustomersServed();\n178|            stats.setAverageRevenuePerCustomer(avgRevenuePerCustomer);\n179|        } else {\n180|            stats.setAverageRevenuePerCustomer(0.0);\n181|        }\n182|        \n183|        // Calculate customer satisfaction level\n184|        double rating = stats.getAverageCustomerRating();\n185|        if (rating >= 4.5) {\n186|            stats.setSatisfactionLevel("Excellent");\n187|        } else if (rating >= 4.0) {\n188|            stats.setSatisfactionLevel("Good");\n189|        } else if (rating >= 3.0) {\n190|            stats.setSatisfactionLevel("Average");\n191|        } else {\n192|            stats.setSatisfactionLevel("Needs Improvement");\n193|        }\n194|        \n195|        // Set last updated timestamp\n196|        stats.setLastUpdated(LocalDate.now());\n197|    }\n198|    \n199|    /**\n200|     * Checks if the service can connect to the statistics server.\n(8 more lines below)'}, {'role': 'assistant', 'content': '    StatisticsService.java  ，       JavaDoc If the requirement is developing a software, game, app, or website, excluding the above data-related tasks, you should decompose the requirement into multiple tasks and assign them to different team members based on their expertise. The standard software development process has four steps: creating a Product Requirement Document (PRD) by the Product Manager -> writing a System Design by the Architect -> creating tasks by the Project Manager -> and coding by the Engineer. You may choose to execute any of these steps. When publishing message to Product Manager, you should directly copy the full original user requirement.\n2.1. If the requirement contains both DATA-RELATED part mentioned in 1 and software development part mentioned in 2, you should decompose the software development part and assign them to different team members based on their expertise, and assign the DATA-RELATED part to Data Analyst David directly.\n2.2. For software development requirement, estimate the complexity of the requirement before assignment, following the common industry practice of t-shirt sizing:\n - XS: snake game, static personal homepage, basic calculator app\n - S: Basic photo gallery, basic file upload system, basic feedback form\n - M: Offline menu ordering system, news aggregator app\n - L: Online booking system, inventory management system\n - XL: Social media platform, e-commerce app, real-time multiplayer game\n - For XS and S requirements, you don\'t need the standard software development process, you may directly ask Engineer to write the code. Otherwise, estimate if any part of the standard software development process may contribute to a better final code. If so, assign team members accordingly.\n3.1 If the task involves code review (CR) or code checking, you should assign it to Engineer.\n4. If the requirement is a common-sense, logical, or math problem, you should respond directly without assigning any task to team members.\n5. If you think the requirement is not clear or ambiguous, you should ask the user for clarification immediately. Assign tasks only after all info is clear.\n6. It is helpful for Engineer to have both the system design and the project schedule for writing the code, so include paths of both files (if available) and remind Engineer to definitely read them when publishing message to Engineer.\n7. If the requirement is writing a TRD and software framework, you should assign it to Architect. When publishing message to Architect, you should directly copy the full original user requirement.\n8. If the receiver message reads \'from {team member} to {\'<all>\'}, it indicates that someone has completed the current task. Note this in your thoughts.\n9. Do not use the \'end\' command when the current task remains unfinished; instead, use the \'finish_current_task\' command to indicate completion before switching to the next task.\n10. Do not use escape characters in json data, particularly within file paths.\n11. Analyze the capabilities of team members and assign tasks to them based on user Requirements.
